results.notes:
Habitat: gregarious in moss, in mixed woods.
Cap: diameters to 38 mm, smooth and dry, inrolled at first, vase-shaped and somewhat lobed at maturity. Bright yellow to pinkish yellow.
Hymenium: false gills decurrent, thick, branching and anastomosing but not cross-veined. Pinkish.
Outer tube: overall length to 33 mm, flared at apex, then equal, about 5 mm in diameter. Solid. Initially mostly yellow but pinkening with maturity. Flesh concolorous.
Odor: none detected.
Taste: not distinctive.
Spore print: very pale cream, with a hint of pink cast.
Note: these mushrooms probably represent the same mycelium as reported from this location by Buyck, et al. They are not the large peach-colored species often described in field guides. Buyck’s molecular work found that species to be a pink form of Cantharellus velutinus.

results.notes:
I checked the exact spot yesterday (on my front lawn), specifically for examples of this taxon, and found none. Thus, this mushroom fruited last night or early this morning. Mature specimen found just after 11 AM today. This one has a rather pale cap surface, although not quite as pale as the photo implies (viewed first-hand a bit more gray). I managed to catch a glimpse of it just before the lawn mower spotted it.

Notable traits include, silvery gray to gray cap often with particles of soil on the surface, fragile membranous basal volva buried in the soil, occurrence in an open grassy area, stipe surface with small white floccose deposits that are easily rubbed off. The basal volva is typically difficult to remove intact from the substrate. The whitish “plate” seen next to the mushroom (3rd photo down) is part of the volval remnant.

Short gill ends truncate to concave.

There are two different spots on my property where I find this type mushroom. Each spot features mature shagbark hickory. In the case of the mushroom seen here, there is little doubt about the symbiont being the large hickory tree. The only other tree close enough to qualify is a red maple that we planted. On this part of the lawn, including a south-facing slope, I have seen hundreds of examples of this taxon over the 17+ summers I have lived here.

Exact location, 239 Golf Course Road, Hunlock Creek, PA.

Scoped spores in several different areas of a print. Length, width, and quotient (Q), were all fairly variable. The majority of the spores seen were ellipsoid. But some were broadly ellipsoid, a few were subglobose, and a very few were elongate (the latter possibly due to partially collapsed lateral spore wall). A few spores appeared with globose profile, although in at least some cases this may be due to a head-on alignment of the spore. But a few rather large ones appeared globose. For the most part, range of dimensions was 9-12 × 7-9, but one really long spore had length ~14 and a few rather short ones had (perceived) lengths ~8.

Regarding spore dimensions for this taxon, over the years I have observed considerable variation… to the point where I wonder if here may be a cryptic species (or maybe a large-spored variety of rooseveltensis) present in the same area. See obs 289181. The one thing about the spores that seems to be constant for this silvery-gray capped taxon with the rooting stipe is that in any given collection most of the spores are ellipsoid.

NAMP accession #58763.

Link to NAMP sequence https://mycomap.com/...

results.notes:
Went for a walk outside my home and spotted this little guy in an oak/hemlock woods about twenty feet away from the road. At first I though it may be one of the small Caesars. But the cap lacks marginal striations. Also, short gills are tapered.

With so much color variation for solaniolens, it’s difficult to believe this name does not actually represent a group of different taxa. This one is completely white, with the exception of a very pale watery-gray disc.

Will confirm section once some spores drop.

results.notes:
On large boulders and cliffs along canyon wall. It made large patches in a few locations. The specimens I noticed were all out of the Yuba River’s spray zone, but it could be that there were some down at the river’s edge. There are quite a few different rock types/layers here, and it is a good lichen spot. Unfortunately, I am not completely sure which one is pictured/don’t remember.
All specimens were on large rocks, so there are no micro data.
Crustose with a distinct, thick grayish-black prothallus in many places, but not completely continuous. The small, rounded areoles (or squamules?) are invariably reddish with a wavy, lobed and upturned margin. This margin has a whitish-gray perimeter that appears to be pruinose.
Apothecia are black, large, with black rims that are almost always taller and “pinched” in appearance.

results.notes:
This is posted on behalf of an experienced forager named TJ Jackson. The specimen was found by the side of a road on private property in West Deer Township in Southwestern PA outside of Pittsburgh. The local woods were a mix of oak and white pine.

Mr. Jackson originally posted this on the Facebook boletes page with the following note: “Blue staining and some red bruising, context yellow, pores still rather stuffed even at this large size. So similar to Baorangia bicolor but just not quite right.”

A sample will be preserved for DNA testing. At least some chemical results will hopefully follow.

NEW INFORMATION: Mr. Jackson reports that he found some younger specimens nearby, and they have a distinct odor of beef bouillon.

results.notes:
Growing in a stand of Norway spruce, not far from a dirt road. Other side if dirt road is a forest of spruce, white pine, hemlock, and hardwoods. No oak in this area.

Large fruit body without universal veil deposits on cap surface, likely due to recent rainfall. Smaller fruit body with a few patches on cap. Completely expanded cap seen in one photo was old and very fragile.

Basal volva of large fruit body broken into pale gray plates distributed on lower stipe surface (a bit atypical for this “strangulated” type). Entire stipe surface with flocose scales, larger and darker on the lower half.

Spores mainly globose, 9.5-11.5.

Not sure about whether the species name “rhacopus” may be confidently applied here.

results.notes: The bolete haul from heaven! Going clockwise from the lovely lady, (1) the biggest collection of Black Velvet Boletes in history, including more in the basket with some chanterelles, (2) Candy Apples, (3) Plumbeoviolaceus to make bitters with, (4) pallidoroseus gone berserk, including an almost-12" mutant. In the middle are some bicolors, subvelutipes, a Leccinum rugociseps, a Xanthoconium, and a single variipes. The brown Tylopilus under the alboater is a badiceps. I think there’s an Old Man in there too. We tossed the felleus and the vermiculosoides, though “jetisoned” may be a better word!

Fishy odor.

Quite frankly, I don’t like this species of mushroom. Some of our local forests fill up with so many of these, that an area along a nice trail may develop a stinking odor as these fungal masses rot. Years back, I tried eating some (actually tasted pretty good filled with a cheesy stuffing and baked). I got sick from them. But, given that this is perhaps our locally most common mycorrhizal mushroom, I feel it would be wrong to leave them out of a project devoted to the Mushrooms of Northeast Pennsylvania. Ans so, NAMP I give you… Russula compacta. Accession #58764.

results.notes:
Very small mushrooms appearing annually (except for years when prohibitive conditions persist) on a mowed path near oak and white pine.

There has existed some potential doubt about whether Amanita minutula represents the same taxon as “Amanita sp-34” which is described on the Amanita Studies Website. The difference is that minutula is described as lacking partial veil, whereas pv is listed as being present with sp-34. I believe this observation may shed light upon this issue. Photos seen here and labeled “B” show a tiny button of the taxon observed (found maybe 2 feet away from the others which are labeled “A”). This button is seen to have a thin fuzzy layer mainly covering the unexpanded gills, but also clinging to the upper stipe. The visual effect is that of a somewhat cortinate partial veil. I have also seen a similar phenomenon on another exannulate Amanita species from section Amanita, A. albocreata (see obs 281869 third photo down themobservations).

Material submitted (both dried and inside the vial for sequencing) taken from mushroom seen in photos A. Once the tiny button was hacked apart and handled, it was IMO not suitable for study.

Spores ellipsoid, 8-10 × 6-7.

results.notes:
These were found in huge profusion at the Lone Pine shelter, about a mile away from the Deer Browse shelters where I found both observation 320877 and observation 244343. These are a much more classic version of pallidoroseus, with pink tones instead of true red and a pronounced odor of beef bouillon. [NOTE: The odor is strongest in mid-sized, mature specimens as opposed to babies and the gigantic, post-mature ones. Could it be related to spore production?]

These specimens also blue a bit more in all parts, though still with hesitation and limits compared to something like subvelutipes or even vermiculosoides. The pores of older specimens blue more than younger ones. There seems to be no difference in the flesh or skin, unless the younger ones blue more on the surface of the stipe. The flesh of all specimens blue more green than blue and it tends to be focused in the base and the edges of the stipe. [NOTE: The photos on the leaves were taken the next day after a night in the refrigerator].

The texture is extraordinarily dense and desirable. Even the gigantic, past-prime, 11-1/2" diameter specimen had a firm texture comparable to a typical bicolor. No bug holes were observed in any specimen, regardless of age.

The weather a week ago was quite rainy. This was followed by intense heat, and then by an evening of torrential rains. I had been by this spot three days ago and did not (from a slow moving car) see any growth.

results.notes:
A single basidiocarp growing in leaf litter in pure deciduous woods about 50-60 yards to the W of the restrooms at Greene Grove. The observed nearby trees (10-15 m radius) were oaks (red, white and chestnut), shagbark hickory, ash and lots of young maples.

Description:
> The unexpanded cap is convex/bell-shaped, with a prominent central umbo, surface appears to be subtly wrinkled/virgate, ivory to very pale cream in color, with a darker creamy disk, 5 cm wide as measured from margin to margin across the center, but with a radius of 3.2 cm as measured from the margin to the center along the cap surface; fine marginal striations are 6-8 mm long (0.19-0.25R); the flesh is dingy white, 7 mm thick above the stipe.
> The gills are white, drying light pinkish-tan, crowded, 4.5 mm wide in the middle; short gills are truncate, plentiful, unevenly distributed, and of various lengths.
> The exannulate stipe is straight in the upper 2/3, curving slightly below, whitish/eggshell, surface somewhat textured (longitudinally striate/streaky), with some appressed powder on the upper 1/3 bearing groves/“scratch marks” of unknown origin (see pix), 13.5 cm long, 9 mm wide at juncture with cap, 7.5 mm wide at its narrowest point (~1.5 cm below apex), gradually widening to 1 cm (~8 cm below apex) and keeping this width down to the base root; the flesh is whitish, discolored brownish in places (due to being waterlogged & insect damaged), somewhat fibrous, with a central canal stuffed with a cottony material
> The universal veil is absent on the cap surface; the volva is a white tubular leathery/membranous sack, 3 cm tall max (longest limb), with a couple of white mycelial threads (rhizomorphs?) attached together with a clump of soil.
> Odor not detected; flesh not tasted.
> Even though the cap failed to expand, the mushroom dropped spores to yield a decent spore print. The spores were mounted in Melzer’s and the following parameters were procured:
[40/1/1]; L X W = (7.4-) 7.7~10.2 × 7.2~9.8 풮m, L’ x W’ = 8.7 × 8.4 풮m; Q = 1.00~1.06 (-1.09), Q’ = 1.04; inamyloid, hyaline, greenish, smooth, thin-walled, with a prominent hilar appendix (apiculus), globose to borderline subglobose (see pix).
There were very, very few spores observed in perfect side-view orientation, and it took a very long time to find them. Unfortunately, most spores oriented in such a fashion were sized below average. Larger than average spores pointed their apiculus down, out of sight, and it was visualized as a grayish blur inside the spore disk when the spore was in focus owing to the spore being hyaline. The apiculus position for such spores ranged from “touching” the spore wall to being perfectly centered inside the spore disk. Of the 40 measured spores only 17 can be described as being in side-view; the remaining 28 spores had their hilar appendices just barely peeking “above the horizon” or dropping slightly below it.
> Comments: Looking from the distance only 1-2 feet, this mushroom originally gave a strong impression of sect. Phalloideae owing to its almost white cap (I almost walked away from it because of this). I decided to excavate it only after realizing there was no annulus. The stipe was inserted 4 cm deep into the ground; at the very least the volva was completely subterranean.

results.notes: Observed in a grassy area surrounded by farm fields. The yard contains mature black walnut trees. This is the second one found in this yard and area within a 2 week period. The growth occurred during an extreme heatwave with high humidity. This mushroom hasn’t been seen here in the previous 11 years. This is a rural home yard frequently mown. The brown juice of this variety of stinkhorn was particularly drippy compared to the first one found. The scent was not overwhelming, but the flies seemed to attracted to it. Day 2 found it continuing to be moist on top. Day three found it to be drooping over and drying out. Day four it was mostly laying over on its side. Day five it was “deflating”. Photos are from day 1. Photos include yard where it was found, one photo with some white twist ties marking the spot as seen from a distance, and then photos close up from varying angles including the egg that it grows from.

results.notes:
Growing in grassy feild. Pasture organic non-gmo grass fed black Angus, pork and chicken are moved around through out the property. Im no expert but Im a farmer and I know a little about the local fungi. I see some Panaeolus subb on the old hay bails and wood shaving that we. Use for compost and theyre brown and bell shaped. These seem quite different. Spore print was black, they vary in size with the length of the grass, some purplish/ blue brusing on base of stem and edges of caps.
My concern is for my chickens. Are they harmful to young chickens??
They dont seem to bother the cattle. Sorry for the terrible pics, and I know I probably could have been a bit more careful with the mushrooms but I was just grabbing them on the go. As an organic farm we dont treat the land with sprays or fertilizers. We make our own naturally. Thanks for any help.

results.notes:
A solitary specimen fruiting in sandy soil, mixed hardwoods and conifer forest. Cap: 5 cm., velvety texture, peachy color covered with a whitish bloom. Stipe 3 cm. X 1.1 cm., essentially equal. Unmistakable odor of dead fish. I was not able to obtain milk or a spore print after specimen had been in the refrigerator for two days; however, brown staining is noted on gills in Images #8717 and #9036, as well as brown staining on flesh (Image #9034 and #9036) where sliced and/or injured. I did not get the expected reaction to KOH (Image #9033) after refrigeration.

I also considered L. corrugis as an ID due to the small areas of corrugation noted at the margin of the cap in several places (Images #8717 and #8720). So, considering all of the above and Kuo’s quote under references, I decided to take “the easy way out” and call this ID “group.” All feedback welcome.

results.notes:
Cap diameter about 4 cm. Stipe length 6-7 cm.

Cap margin tuberculate-striate, striations deeply seated and occupying 35%-45% of radius.

Cap with dark brown umbo transitioning to a cream-colored margin. Colors in first photo are accurate.

Stipe with dense floccose material, easily brushed away. Stipe surface shredding in some areas.

Stipe buried to about the upper margin of the volva. Volva membranous, persistent, and somewhat rubbery.

Spores mainly globose, some subglobose. 9-12 × 9-12. (One seemingly large spore seen in the photo appears to actually be two spores stuck together.

Mowed path near fairly young oaks (~20 feet tall). White pine in the vicinity, also fairly young trees.

This is the best match for the specimen originally used to represent the provisionally named Amanita cyclops that I have found. Same exact location as the type specimen. I have observed a number of other fruit bodies in this same 4 square yard area that likely represent the same taxon. But, not many of them manage to remain in-situ until maturity, due to this material apparently being a favorite food for slugs. The recent spell of dry weather probably helped this critter (although some slug damage is apparent). This mushroom fruited during dry weather. Only <0.01 inch rainfall during the 3.5 days leading up to my finding it. Not more than 30 hours previous to this discovery, I had carefully checked the location and this mushroom was not present at that time. Other fruit bodies observed in this location over the past 3 years (possibly representing the same taxon) have featured unexpanded caps. In most of these cases, the umbo is prominent, but gray instead of brown (except for the type specimen). Spore dimensions for these other collections match this observation very well.

For additional details see http://www.amanitaceae.org/?Amanita+cyclops .
